thread.title: Conservatives claim second victory as McCarthy quits race
thread.title_full: Conservatives claim second victory as McCarthy quits race - POLITICO

author: Todd S. Purdum
title: Conservatives claim second victory as McCarthy quits race
text:
NASHUA, N.H. — Conservatives couldn’t contain their glee over Kevin McCarthy’s decision to drop his bid for the House speakership on Thursday, claiming another casualty in their push to drive congressional Republicans to the right. "Oh my gosh, we're winning, this is excellent!" Jenny Beth Martin, the co-founder of the Tea Party Patriots, told POLITICO. "The grassroots have been working on this for years and the members who went into that conference, they held firm and we are so appreciative that they did that."
Nationwide, movement conservatives celebrated, seeing McCarthy’s decision as their second victory after John Boehner announced he would resign . Libertarian activists gathered in New Hampshire for a Republican Liberty Caucus convention said years of action to force Washington to recognize the anger pulsing through the populist wing of the Republican Party was finally showing results.
"It's a sign that we're finally seeing the anger crossing the country make its way into DC,” said Matt Nye, the chairman of the caucus.
The House Republican Freedom Caucus deserved particular plaudits for McCarthy's decision, argued Drew Ryun, the political director for The Madison Project. On Wednesday, that group of conservative lawmakers endorsed Rep. Daniel Webster for speaker over McCarthy.
"I think it's a new day for conservatives," Ryun said. "I mean this House Freedom Caucus, everybody was wondering when they would have some conservative victories. … Make no mistake they had a role in (McCarthy’s decision.) That is their first legislative victory. That will dictate legislation going forward."
Webster wasn’t the only name uttered in Nashua as activists discussed possible House speakers. Di Lothrop, program chair of the Republican Liberty Caucus convention, named Jason Chaffetz as a better conservative candidate than McCarthy.
After McCarthy's exit, who's in the running to replace Boehner? By Lauren French
Republicans on the presidential campaign trail also cheered the news, and aimed to align themselves with the conservative voices channeling the right’s frustration with Washington.
“Every elected congressman and every elected senator should be very aware that the grassroots is unhappy,” Sen. Rand Paul, a 2016 contender whose candidacy had been based on his libertarian and anti-establishment roots, said on Fox News. “They're very upset that official Washington does not appear to be using the full force of our office. They wonder why they expended so much effort to elect conservatives and then it turns out they're not using their full force."
And Sen. Ted Cruz, one of the most conservative Republicans in the 2016 field and an ally to the House conservatives, called on GOP leaders to start listening.
“Leadership isn’t listening or honoring promises they made to the American people,” Cruz said during an interview on a local Boston radio station. “The volcanic frustration with Washington spilled over, spilled over to a point where every one of us was sick and tired of leadership who doesn’t stand up and fight Obama on anything.”
Eliza Collins contributed to this report.
